text:
IN THE CROWN COURT AT NOTTINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No. N2025/20965  
Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. J. TOWNSEND  
Filed: 24 September 2025  

The defendant, Mr H, appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period relevant to the offending spans from late 2022 until his arrest on 17 April 2025.  

Mr H’s case has been subject to extensive procedural steps, including multiple listings, adjournments, and various applications by both the prosecution and the defence. The initial hearing took place on 14 May 2025, followed by a plea and trial preparation hearing on 11 August 2025. The matter came before the jury on 2 September 2025, concluding with a verdict of guilty pronounced on 18 September 2025. The court acknowledges the considerable efforts of all those involved in ensuring the continuation of proceedings despite common delays occasioned by resource constraints, personnel strike action affecting court staff in July, and, regrettably, a brief closure owing to the discovery of asbestos in Court 5 during fumigation works.  

At the outset, it must be noted that the defendant benefited from the assignment of defence counsel under the Legal Aid Scheme, represented throughout by Mr Michael Dalrymple, who is to be commended for his diligent advocacy despite encountering administrative difficulties arising from the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted authorisation of expert instructions. These delays have become a regrettably frequent feature of serious criminal litigation and have materially impacted preparation timelines. Such bureaucratic friction sits uneasily alongside the overarching imperative of the timely administration of justice, a principle enshrined in section 1 of the Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996.  

The court further records its appreciation for Ms Harriet Myles, prosecuting on behalf of the Crown, whose conduct of the case has been measured, professional, and resolutely committed to the considerations of evidential sufficiency and victim dignity. It is also appropriate to acknowledge the indispensable role played by the Special Branch of Nottinghamshire Police and Counter Terrorism Policing East Midlands in the investigation and arrest of the defendant—a coordinated endeavour involving extensive cross-agency collaboration, challenged both by technical complexities and operational pressures.  

Prior to delving into the particulars of the offending conduct, it is pertinent to reflect upon certain procedural norms and historic parallels drawn from appellate authority that inform the imposition of sentence in cases of this gravity. In particular, the court recalls the seminal decision in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, where the Supreme Court delineated the parameters of “terrorist purpose” with clarity, underscoring that the offence encompasses conduct that is preparatory to wide-ranging act(s), not necessarily consummated in the commission of violence itself. Similarly instructive is the Court of Appeal’s ruling in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, which emphasised the gravity inherent in the mere possession of articles with a terrorist purpose, particularly where corroborated by other conduct evidencing intent.  

The doctrine of guilty plea credit is well-established, yet increasingly nuanced in the contemporary landscape. The prudent imposition of sentence must consider not only the timing of the plea but the extent to which such admission affords genuine mitigation, measured against the overall impact on court resources and victim welfare. The court notes with some concern a growing trend towards last-minute pleas, as exemplified in several illustrative authorities, including R v. Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029 and R v. McKinnon [2021] EWCA Crim 2145, which have clarified that credit must be moderated where pleas follow exhaustive preparatory hearings and the near inevitability of conviction becomes apparent.  

In fairness to the defence, the court recognises that such delay may sometimes stem from a strategic determination to ensure the fullest possible review of voluminous material; however, the administration of justice cannot be subordinated to tactical expediency. Accordingly, the court will approach plea credit with circumspection appropriate to the circumstances.  

Mr H was arrested at 05:20 on 17 April 2025 pursuant to a warrant authorised by a District Judge under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The warrant concerned a residential property on Langley Road in Beeston, Nottingham, executed by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing East Midlands, supported by technicians and forensic specialists from the National Digital Exploitation Unit. The operation followed a period of sustained investigation over several months grounded in intelligence reports and intercepted communications. The material obtained included a laptop computer encrypted with sophisticated cryptographic software and various electronic devices, all of which underwent exhaustive examination for evidential content.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}

The investigatory team drew upon state-of-the-art digital forensic methodologies, complicated by the defendant’s habitual use of anonymisation networks, live VPNs, and Tor-browser-protected messaging applications. This created a significant challenge, necessitating collaboration with cybercrime specialists at the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU), who undertook painstaking decryption efforts. These interdisciplinary efforts were further hampered by the defendant’s apparent use of burner phones and dual-subscriber identity modules (SIMs), which required complex cell-site analysis to establish pattern-of-life correlations.  

Unconnected to the matter at hand, it is worth noting an incident earlier in 2024 involving the illicit disposal of waste in the green belt just outside Nottingham, which has had a ripple effect on the staffing capacity of environmental regulatory authorities in the region. Though unrelated to the defendant, such matters underscore the increasing strain placed on public enforcement agencies across a range of issues compounded by budgetary constraints.  

The court also takes judicial notice of the report submitted by the East Midlands Fire and Rescue Service concerning an arson attack on a disused tobacco warehouse in Long Eaton. While the arsonists were never apprehended, this incident led to some temporary disruption in court listings earlier this year due to the necessity of diverting fire investigation personnel.  

The defendant was initially granted conditional bail on 3 May 2025, subject to standard undertaking provisions, including electronic tagging and residence at a specified address pending trial. However, bail was revoked on 2 July 2025 following fresh intelligence indicating ongoing covert communications between the defendant and persons outside the jurisdiction aligned with proscribed organisations. The Crown applied successfully for remand to ensure public protection and prevent risk of further preparatory activity.  

In reviewing the evidence, the court also considered the impact of certain co-defendant actions and unrelated proceedings. One such co-defendant, Mr J, charged with offences involving possession of a bladed article and associated affray in a public house, absconded prior to trial. Despite exhaustive searches and police activity, he remains at large. It must be emphasised that such behaviour has no bearing on the defendant’s culpability but has contributed to logistical challenges in assembling joint trial bundles.  

It is informative to bear in mind the relevant legal precedents on sentencing methodology. The statutory framework governing sentencing for terrorism offences derives principally from the Terrorism Act 2006 and is supplemented by the Sentencing Council’s definitive 2023 guidelines. The latter provide attendance on aggravating and mitigating factors, including the offender’s degree of planning and preparation, association with recognised terrorist entities, potential for harm, and timeliness of plea. Noteworthy is the guidance articulated in R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678, which laid emphasis on deterrence and the protection of the public as paramount considerations.  

The court was provided with a detailed pre-sentence report from the National Probation Service. The report, prepared by Senior Probation Officer Louise Abbey, details Mr H’s background in some depth. Mr H, now aged 31, received a degree in electrical engineering from the University of Derby but has no recorded history of serious convictions. Officer Abbey stresses, however, a concerning pattern of social withdrawal and increasing fixation on extremist ideological content from 2022 onwards. The pre-sentence report also addresses Mr H’s prior history of transient employment interspersed with periods of unemployment and notes an incident of shoplifting from a local supermarket dating back to 2011.  

Such minor criminal conduct, while recorded, falls well outside the sentencing considerations for terrorism and is referenced here only to provide a holistic view of Mr H’s personal history. The court is also aware of a record maintained by the City of Nottingham Police of a noise abatement notice served on the landlord of Mr H’s previous residence in Carlton, associated with disturbances caused by unrelated tenants. These peripheral details have no direct or indirect bearing on the present offending.  

In assessing risk, the court gave considerable weight to the psychiatric report prepared by Dr Harold Byram, a consultant forensic psychiatrist seconded from the Lincolnshire NHS Trust. Dr Byram’s assessment, conducted over three sessions in August and September 2025, concludes that Mr H exhibits a marked rigidity of thought and a pronounced intolerance of opposing viewpoints, factors viewed as elevating concern regarding potential for recidivist activity in extremist matters. That said, Dr Byram found no diagnosable psychotic or affective disorder. The report cautions that risk management will require interagency collaboration, including secure accommodation and vigilant monitoring of digital communications upon any eventual release.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}  

The defendant’s online activity demonstrated escalating support for violent extremist ideologies. A blog, hosted on an obscure platform, evolved over the period of the offending from seemingly innocuous political commentary to explicit calls for destabilisation and retribution upon perceived enemies of his cause. Analysis by linguistic experts revealed congruence with known propaganda materials promulgated by proscribed groups internationally.  

The court also notes the discovery of devices and printed materials detailing explosive manufacture techniques. Importantly, such materials were stored in encrypted partitions, consistent with behaviours bearing hallmarks of preparatory acts directed towards mass casualty incidents.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}   

Among the recovered digital content were encrypted manifestos and detailed instructions on the manufacture of improvised explosive devices. These instructions included, inter alia, discussions on chemical compositions, detonation circuitry, and tactical placement to maximise injury. In mitigation, the defence contended that the presence of some such materials might be explained by Mr H’s avowed interest in chemistry and pyrotechnics as a hobby. The court, accepting the expert evidence presented, rejects any benign explanation consistent with isolated hobbyist engagement given the context of the defendant’s wider conduct.  

It is sometimes observed that criminal cases are complicated by the presence of extraneous evidence or collateral charges relating to third parties. During the investigation, it emerged that the defendant's roommate was found to be in possession of small quantities of cannabis during a separate police search unrelated to terrorism allegations. Additionally, a distant relative of Mr H stands under investigation for benefit fraud, a matter still sub judice. Neither of these facts, while recorded, bears upon the issues before the court today.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}  

The defendant’s use of social media also evidenced a pattern of networking with extremist sympathisers domestically and overseas. The content of private messages included references to “martyrdom operations” and “just retribution” for military interventions abroad. Though the defence posit that such writings constitute protected political speech or hyperbole, this court finds no merit in such submissions in light of established jurisprudence reinforcing that speech intended to incite or facilitate terrorism falls outside protected expression.  

Notably, the Crown adduced evidence of Mr H attending an event in a neighbouring city under the pretext of a photography workshop; surveillance and telecommunications data indicated he made contact with known facilitators subsequently convicted of providing material support to terrorist organisations. This connectivity provides important context for sentencing, suggesting a high degree of commitment beyond casual interest.  

It is, however, necessary to reflect on certain unrelated historical decisions which help frame sentencing discretion in preparatory terrorism cases. In R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, the Court of Appeal considered the application of sentencing principles where mental disorder interfaced with culpability. There the defendant, who suffered from schizoaffective disorder, committed arson at multiple properties causing extensive damage and risk to life. The court highlighted the distinction between cause and culpability, mandating sentences that reflect both public protection and the therapeutic dimension. While Mr H does not have such a diagnosis, the careful balance outlined remains instructive.  

Further, the case of R v. Bhandari [2023] EWCA Crim 412 clarified that community-based psychiatric support, while valuable, cannot supplant custodial sentences where there is a demonstrated pattern of escalating harm and resistance to treatment. These authorities underscore the need for calibrated sentences that reconcile individual circumstances with the overriding public safety mandate.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}  

Mr H’s travel history indicates a documented visit to Istanbul in April 2024, purportedly to attend a conference on humanitarian aid logistics. Records obtained from immigration show attempts to proceed further to a conflict-adjacent zone, though this final leg was frustrated by unforeseen travel disruption. This evidence aligns closely with interdiction patterns seen in other cases where ostensibly legitimate travel provides cover for connecting with extremist operatives.  

As the Crown notes, the question of proximate intent is supported by these attempts to embed within hostile environments conducive to militant activity. Defence submissions emphasize that Mr H did not complete the journey and question any ultimate plan; the court however, must evaluate conduct both in intention and steps taken.  

It is relevant to observe the broader context within which such investigations unfold. Disclosure processes in complex terrorism cases now commonly require examination of thousands of digital items, redacted across various secure platforms, as described in the case of R v. AB & CD [2014] EWCA Crim 354. The balance between open justice and national security continues to pose formidable operational challenges, frequently necessitating closed material procedures and the involvement of specialist judges.  

The court is acutely aware that the investigations consume tangible and intangible public resources; it is not unheard of for similar inquiries to consume hundreds of person-hours from intelligence analysts, digital forensic experts, and uniformed officers whose redeployment creates a ripple effect across other pressing public safety concerns, including investigations into organised crime and violent offences.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}  

Financial tracing of blockchain transactions revealed that Mr H transferred the sum of approximately £3,200 in cryptocurrency to wallets linked to darknet marketplaces known to purchase controlled chemical precursors. Such transactions evince an intention to procure materials for illicit purposes. The court notes the growing sophistication of criminals in using decentralised finance to obscure transactional flows—techniques which law enforcement is struggling to keep pace with. The opacity inherent in these technologies multiplies the risks to the public and complicates risk management strategies.  

Along these lines, the court acknowledges the difficult balance between advancement in digital innovation honoured in commercial spheres and the criminal exploitation thereof. Cautionary remarks made by this court regarding over-reliance on technological solutions in enforcement echo concerns expressed by senior figures in the National Crime Agency. It remains an area of pressing legislative and operational attention.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}  

Turning to personal background, Mr H is a 31-year-old man with a university education in electrical engineering. Prior work history includes employment as a junior design technician with a Midlands manufacturing firm until his abrupt resignation in August 2023. His line manager describes him as “meticulous and conscientious” though prone to social isolation. There is no suggestion of prior violent offending. Letters of support have been submitted from a local allotment association praising Mr H’s commitment to communal gardening, and a faith-based charity endorsing his efforts in foodbank volunteering during the 2020 Covid-19 lockdowns.  

While such community involvement is commendable, it must not be misconstrued as indicative of diminished culpability where the seriousness of the offence is manifest. The duality of character is not uncommon, and courts have recognised in cases such as R v. Varlow [2022] EWCA Crim 928 that prosocial conduct does not negate responsibility for extremist offending.  

The defendant has provided a letter directly to the court, thoughtful in tone, expressing regret for the effect of his actions on the community. That communication has been taken into account with due weight.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}  

The clinical psychologist, Dr Felicity Crane, offering an expert forensic report in this case, characterises Mr H as exhibiting “elevated cognitive rigidity accompanied by a binary worldview and a sustained fascination with apocalyptic narratives.” No formal diagnosis of psychiatric disorder was made. Importantly, Dr Crane flags a high risk of serious harm linked to ideological convictions and the potential for relapse into fascilitating activities absent stringent management. Suggestions for mitigation include enrolment in the Countering Violent Extremism Programme (CVE) and high-intensity cognitive behavioural therapy.  

In weighing mitigation, the court acknowledges the defendant’s lack of prior criminal convictions and the partial engagement with deradicalisation initiatives while on bail. However, the gravity of the offending and the strategic nature of preparation command a sentence of considerable severity. The submission made by defence counsel for a non-custodial disposal is respectfully rejected.  

It is necessary to reiterate that the purpose of sentencing in terrorism matters encompasses denunciation, deterrence, and most importantly, protection of the public. Those who engage in preparatory activity for acts designed to sow fear and disorder strike at the heart of our social fabric. The court must send a clear message that such conduct invites significant custodial consequences proportionate to culpability.  

The court will now direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, with particular emphasis upon risk management recommendations, licence conditions, and the prospect of engagement with multi-agency monitoring frameworks including MAPPA Category 3 supervision. The report should also consider the suitability and availability of the Extended Determinate Sentence pursuant to section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, tailored interventions for disengagement from extremist ideology, and the feasibility of imposing electronic monitoring and internet access restrictions post-release.  

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 24 September 2025, in Court 2 at Nottingham Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities for registration. The defendant is reminded of his right of appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved.  

These are the orders of the court.

While such community involvement is commendable, it must not be misconstrued as indicative of diminished culpability where the seriousness of the offence is manifest. The duality of character is not uncommon, and courts have recognised in cases such as R v. Varlow [2022] EWCA Crim 928 that prosocial conduct does not negate responsibility for extremist offending.  

The defendant has provided a letter directly to the court, thoughtful in tone, expressing regret for the effect of his actions on the community. That communication has been taken into account with due weight.  

A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians.  

The clinical psychologist, Dr Felicity Crane, offering an expert forensic report in this case, characterises Mr H as exhibiting “elevated cognitive rigidity accompanied by a binary worldview and a sustained fascination with apocalyptic narratives.” No formal diagnosis of psychiatric disorder was made. Importantly, Dr Crane flags a high risk of serious harm linked to ideological convictions and the potential for relapse into fascilitating activities absent stringent management. Suggestions for mitigation include enrolment in the Countering Violent Extremism Programme (CVE) and high-intensity cognitive behavioural therapy.  

In weighing mitigation, the court acknowledges the defendant’s lack of prior criminal convictions and the partial engagement with deradicalisation initiatives while on bail. However, the gravity of the offending and the strategic nature of preparation command a sentence of considerable severity. The submission made by defence counsel for a non-custodial disposal is respectfully rejected.  

It is necessary to reiterate that the purpose of sentencing in terrorism matters encompasses denunciation, deterrence, and most importantly, protection of the public. Those who engage in preparatory activity for acts designed to sow fear and disorder strike at the heart of our social fabric. The court must send a clear message that such conduct invites significant custodial consequences proportionate to culpability.  

The court will now direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, with particular emphasis upon risk management recommendations, licence conditions, and the prospect of engagement with multi-agency monitoring frameworks including MAPPA Category 3 supervision. The report should also consider the suitability and availability of the Extended Determinate Sentence pursuant to section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, tailored interventions for disengagement from extremist ideology, and the feasibility of imposing electronic monitoring and internet access restrictions post-release.  

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 24 September 2025, in Court 2 at Nottingham Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities for registration. The defendant is reminded of his right of appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved.
